qas.question: What nullified patent claims of EDVAC designers?

answers.text: von Neumann wrote an incomplete First Draft of a Report

qas.question: What was the significance of EDVAC?

answers.text: architecture is to this day the basis of modern computer design,

context: While consulting for the Moore School of Electrical Engineering at the University of Pennsylvania on the EDVAC project, <a0_0>von Neumann wrote an incomplete First Draft of a Report<a0_0/> on the EDVAC. The paper, whose premature distribution nullified the patent claims of EDVAC designers J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly, described a computer architecture in which the data and the program are both stored in the computer's memory in the same address space. This <a1_0>architecture is to this day the basis of modern computer design,<a1_0/> unlike the earliest computers that were "programmed" using a separate memory device such as a paper tape or plugboard. Although the single-memory, stored program architecture is commonly called von Neumann architecture as a result of von Neumann's paper, the architecture's description was based on the work of J. Presper Eckert and John William Mauchly, inventors of the ENIAC computer at the <a2_0>University of Pennsylvania<a2_0/>.
